t: Isaiah 33
Distress and Help

Woe*pn to you, destroyer, you*ld who have not been destroyed! Woe*ln to you, betrayer, you*ld who have not been betrayed! When*ln you stop destroying, you*ld will be destroyed; when*ln you stop betraying, you*ld will be betrayed.
Lord,*spn be gracious to us; we*ld long for you. Be*ln our strength every morning, our*ld salvation in time of distress.
At*ln the uproar of your army, the peoples flee; when*ld you rise up, the nations scatter.
Your*ln plunder, O nations, is harvested as by young locusts; like*ld a swarm of locusts people pounce on it.
The*pn Lord*s is exalted, for he dwells on high; he*ld will fill Zion with his justice and righteousness.
He*ln will be the sure foundation for your times, a*ld rich store of salvation and wisdom and knowledge; the*ld fear of the Lord*s is the key to this treasure.
Look,*pn their brave men cry aloud in the streets; the*ld envoys of peace weep bitterly.
The*ln highways are deserted, no*ld travelers are on the roads. The*ln treaty is broken, its*ld witnesses are despised, no*ld one is respected.
The*ln land dries up and wastes away, Lebanon*ld is ashamed and withers; Sharon*ln is like the Arabah, and*ld Bashan and Carmel drop their leaves.
“Now*pn will I arise,” says the Lord.*s “Now*ld will I be exalted; now*ld will I be lifted up.
You*ln conceive chaff, you*ld give birth to straw; your*ld breath is a fire that consumes you.
The*ln peoples will be burned to ashes; like*ld cut thornbushes they will be set ablaze.”
You*pn who are far away, hear what I have done; you*ld who are near, acknowledge my power!
The*ln sinners in Zion are terrified; trembling*ld grips the godless: “Who*ln of us can dwell with the consuming fire? Who*ld of us can dwell with everlasting burning?”

Those*ln who walk righteously and*ld speak what is right, who*ln reject gain from extortion and*ld keep their hands from accepting bribes, who*ln stop their ears against plots of murder and*ld shut their eyes against contemplating evil—
they*ln are the ones who will dwell on the heights, whose*ld refuge will be the mountain fortress. Their*ln bread will be supplied, and*ld water will not fail them.
Your*pn eyes will see the king in his beauty and*ld view a land that stretches afar.
In*ln your thoughts you will ponder the former terror: “Where*ld is that chief officer? Where*ln is the one who took the revenue? Where*ld is the officer in charge of the towers?”
You*ln will see those arrogant people no more, people*ld whose speech is obscure, whose*ld language is strange and incomprehensible.
Look*pn on Zion, the city of our festivals; your*ld eyes will see Jerusalem, a*ld peaceful abode, a tent that will not be moved; its*ln stakes will never be pulled up, nor*ld any of its ropes broken.
There*ln the Lord*s will be our Mighty One. It*ld will be like a place of broad rivers and streams. No*ln galley with oars will ride them, no*ld mighty ship will sail them.
For*ln the Lord*s is our judge, the*ld Lord*s is our lawgiver, the*ln Lord*s is our king; it*ld is he who will save us.
Your*pn rigging hangs loose: The*ld mast is not held secure, the*ld sail is not spread. Then*ln an abundance of spoils will be divided and*ld even the lame will carry off plunder.
No*ln one living in Zion will say, “I am ill”; and*ld the sins of those who dwell there will be forgiven.
